content: How can I help you today?
I'm not sure. My wife thought I should come in and talk, but honestly, I feel like I'm in such a mess that I don't even know where to start. Things just feel overwhelming right now.

It shows a lot of courage to share that, especially when things feel overwhelming. It sounds like you're carrying a lot right now. How do you feel about what brought you here and your wife's suggestion?

I guess she thinks talking to someone might help, but I'm not sure. Things at home are just really hard—our son is having a tough time, my wife and I are struggling, and I feel like I’m failing as a husband and father. I just don’t know if talking about it will make a difference.

It sounds like you're trying to balance a lot—being there for your son, supporting your wife, and dealing with your own feelings in the mix. That sense of feeling like you're not doing enough as a husband and father must weigh heavily. It’s understandable to question whether talking about it can help. What do you think has felt the hardest for you lately?

I think it’s just that nothing feels like it’s working. No matter what we try with my son, his behavior isn’t improving, and it’s putting so much strain on my marriage. I feel helpless and like I can’t get anything right, whether it’s with him, my wife, or even at work. It’s like everything’s falling apart all at once.

It must be really painful to feel like everything is unraveling, despite your efforts to set things right. It sounds like you're trying so hard to help your son, support your wife, and stay on top of work, but all of it combined feels like it's slipping out of your control. What keeps you going, even when it feels so hard?

Honestly, what keeps me going right now is just the thought of my family. I still want to figure out how to help my son. I don't want to give up on my wife and daughter either. Even though it feels like everything’s a mess, I know I care about them more than anything.

Your commitment to your family really shines through, even during tough times like this. Wanting to figure things out and not giving up shows so much dedication and love. How do you see yourself being there for your family, even amidst all these challenges?

I don’t really know right now. I feel like I’m just barely holding it together, and I don’t even know what “being there” looks like anymore. I guess I just want to feel like I’m doing something that actually helps instead of feeling stuck.

It seems like feeling stuck has been really frustrating for you, especially when all you want is to help your family and make things better. Wanting to take action that actually makes a difference shows how much you care. What do you think could help you get to that place where you feel less stuck?

I don’t know... maybe figuring out how to handle things differently? But honestly, I don’t even know where to start. It just feels like there’s so much to figure out, and I’m scared it might be too late to fix everything.

It’s understandable to feel overwhelmed and fear that it's too late, especially when things feel so big and uncertain. At the same time, just recognizing that something needs to change—and being open to exploring what that could look like—shows a lot of strength. If you were to take even a small step forward, what would that look like for you?

Honestly, I wouldn’t even know where to start. Maybe trying to talk to my wife more about how we can work together or even just figuring out ways to handle my stress. I guess everything just feels like a huge mountain to climb right now.

That mountain can feel so daunting, especially when trying to tackle everything at once. Even considering small steps, like talking with your wife or addressing your own stress, could be meaningful ways to start. What feels like the most manageable step to focus on today, even if it’s small?

Maybe starting with talking to my wife could help, but I don’t even know if she’d want to hear how I’m feeling when she’s going through so much herself. I guess I don’t want to make things harder for her, but I also want us to be on the same page.

It makes sense that you'd worry about not wanting to add to her stress, especially given everything she's facing too. Wanting to be on the same page with her shows how much you value your connection and partnership. What do you think could help open that conversation with her in a way that feels supportive for both of you?

Maybe I could just let her know how much I care about her and our family, and that I want us to work together to figure things out. I don’t want it to feel like I’m blaming her, but more like I’m asking how we can team up to get through this. I think that might be a good place to start.

That sounds like a thoughtful and caring approach. Letting her know how much you care and emphasizing teamwork could really help create a space for the two of you to feel heard and supported. Is there anything else you'd like to explore or talk about before moving forward with this idea?
I don’t think so right now. I feel like I’ve got something to start with, and I appreciate you helping me talk through this. Thank you for listening.
